TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit OverScroller extends Java.Lang.Object

Docs.summary: This class encapsulates scrolling with the ability to overshoot the bounds of a scrolling operation.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void Fling (int startX, int startY, int velocityX, int velocityY, int minX, int maxX, int minY, int maxY);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void Fling(int32 startX, int32 startY, int32 velocityX, int32 velocityY, int32 minX, int32 maxX, int32 minY, int32 maxY) cil managed
abstract member Fling : int * int * int * int * int * int * int * int -> unit override this.Fling : int * int * int * int * int * int * int * int -> unit
MemberSignature.Usage: overScroller.Fling (startX, startY, velocityX, velocityY, minX, maxX, minY, maxY)

Docs.param: Starting point of the scroll (X)
Starting point of the scroll (Y)
Initial velocity of the fling (X) measured in pixels per second.
Initial velocity of the fling (Y) measured in pixels per second
Minimum X value. The scroller will not scroll past this point unless overX > 0. If overfling is allowed, it will use minX as a springback boundary.
Maximum X value. The scroller will not scroll past this point unless overX > 0. If overfling is allowed, it will use maxX as a springback boundary.
Minimum Y value. The scroller will not scroll past this point unless overY > 0. If overfling is allowed, it will use minY as a springback boundary.
Maximum Y value. The scroller will not scroll past this point unless overY > 0. If overfling is allowed, it will use maxY as a springback boundary.
Overfling range. If > 0, horizontal overfling in either direction will be possible.
Overfling range. If > 0, vertical overfling in either direction will be possible.
Docs.summary: Start scrolling based on a fling gesture.

format.a: Java documentation for android.widget.OverScroller.fling(int, int, int, int, int, int, int, int, int, int).

remarks.para: Portions of this page are modifications based on work created and shared by the Android Open Source Project and used according to terms described in the Creative Commons 2.5 Attribution License.

Maximum X value. The scroller will not scroll past this point unless overX > 0. If overfling is allowed, it will use maxX as a springback boundary.

Maximum Y value. The scroller will not scroll past this point unless overY > 0. If overfling is allowed, it will use maxY as a springback boundary.
Overfling range. If > 0, horizontal overfling in either direction will be possible.
Overfling range. If > 0, vertical overfling in either direction will be possible.

Docs.summary: Returns whether the current Scroller is currently returning to a valid position.

Docs.param: Starting/current X position
Desired final X position
Magnitude of overscroll allowed. This should be the maximum desired distance from finalX. Absolute value - must be positive.
Docs.summary: Notify the scroller that we've reached a horizontal boundary.

Starting Y coordinate
Minimum valid X value
Maximum valid X value

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void StartScroll (int startX, int startY, int dx, int dy);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void StartScroll(int32 startX, int32 startY, int32 dx, int32 dy) cil managed
abstract member StartScroll : int * int * int * int -> unit override this.StartScroll : int * int * int * int -> unit

Docs.param: Starting horizontal scroll offset in pixels. Positive numbers will scroll the content to the left.
Starting vertical scroll offset in pixels. Positive numbers will scroll the content up.
Horizontal distance to travel. Positive numbers will scroll the content to the left.
Vertical distance to travel. Positive numbers will scroll the content up.
Docs.summary: Start scrolling by providing a starting point and the distance to travel.

format.a: Java documentation for android.widget.OverScroller.startScroll(int, int, int, int).

remarks.para: Portions of this page are modifications based on work created and shared by the Android Open Source Project and used according to terms described in the Creative Commons 2.5 Attribution License.

abstract member StartScroll : int * int * int * int * int -> unit override this.StartScroll : int * int * int * int * int -> unit

Docs.param: Duration of the scroll in milliseconds.
Starting horizontal scroll offset in pixels. Positive numbers will scroll the content to the left.
Starting vertical scroll offset in pixels. Positive numbers will scroll the content up.
Horizontal distance to travel. Positive numbers will scroll the content to the left.
Vertical distance to travel. Positive numbers will scroll the content up.
Docs.summary: Start scrolling by providing a starting point and the distance to travel.

format.a: Java documentation for android.widget.OverScroller.startScroll(int, int, int, int).
